body:
Hey @sirmarcel ,

I am not sure why someone would train a model until convergence and then run `trainer.train()` again, without changing the lr-settings :D
Saving `self._stop` to the state dict would prohibit any retraining of the model at all. In case someone uses the `MaxEpochHook`, trains the model for x epochs and then tries to train for some more epochs, it would be the easiest to overwrite the `MaxEpochHook` with a different number of epochs. `trainer.train()` would still not do anything, because `self._stop = True`. Maybe I could add a `on_train_begin`-function to the `ReduceOnPlateau`-hook, which checks if the lr is already below the min_lr. This would then stop the training directly if the `min_lr` has not been updated.
Does this sound good to you?

Hi Stefan,

> I am not sure why someone would train a model until convergence and then run trainer.train() again, without changing the lr-settings :D

That's a good question ðŸ˜† ! In my case, I was just testing some automation on top of `Trainer` and was confused that it kept running after converging initially. I would expect the `Trainer` to either be finished or not, independently of whether it was restored from a checkpoint, so running `.train()` should run at most one step before finishing again. 

Thanks for explaining the idea behind not saving `_stop`! In my case, the actual culprit is the `EarlyStoppingHook`, which I was also using, but forgot to mention. (I'm using the plateau hook without its `min_lr` option, so it's not responsible for terminating the training.)

The `EarlyStoppingHook` doesn't save the `best_loss` to its own `state_dict`, so when it gets restored, it automatically resets its counter to 0 (since it initialises with `best_loss = float("inf)`). Therefore, a recovered `Trainer` with early stopping will always run for at least the `patience` of the hook. Would you consider this a bug? I guess in some cases it might be preferable to get "another chance" at training further, but maybe the correct way to achieve that is to modify the hooks?

Hey Marcel,

> The EarlyStoppingHook doesn't save the best_loss to its own state_dict, so when it gets restored, it automatically resets its counter to 0 (since it initialises with best_loss = float("inf)). Therefore, a recovered Trainer with early stopping will always run for at least the patience of the hook.

Oh ok, I think it would be good to also store the `best_loss`. I am not sure what the best behaviour for converged models is. Since e.g. the `MaxEpochHook` directly aborts training, when the maximum number of epochs is reached, it would make sence to also use this behaviour for other stop-hooks.
@ktschuett : Should converged models be able to train until they converge again (without an update of the Hook-parameters), or should the training be aborted at the beginning of training?

> @ktschuett : Should converged models be able to train until they converge again (without an update of the Hook-parameters), or should the training be aborted at the beginning of training?

I think the trainng should abort directly if you don't change the patience or any other training parameter. It should behave as if it never was interupted.
Ok, I will have a look at the hooks and fix them if necessary.

issue.title: ENH: Restore EarlyStoppingHook state from checkpoint.

repository.name: schnetpack
repository.description: SchNetPack - Deep Neural Networks for Atomistic Systems

issue.body:
This should fix #239 by making two changes:
- Store the best loss in the hook's `state_dict`.
- Ensuring `Trainer` uses the actual hook `state_dict` for restore.

Note that the changes to `Trainer` might break some workflows that involve adding or removing hooks before restoring from a checkpoint: this will now fail if the `state_dict` that is restored doesn't match the new hook setup. There should probably be a check to see if the setups match... or a separate method to do a "less thorough" restore.

body: Took the liberty of opening a PR (#243) to fix this issue, I think as discussed!

Hey @sirmarcel ,
thanks for your contribution. The PR has been merged now :)

issue.title: Logging hook gets stuck when restarting training

repository.name: schnetpack
repository.description: SchNetPack - Deep Neural Networks for Atomistic Systems

issue.body:
Hey, it's me again.

I noticed the learning rate was getting stuck to a certain value in the log, but the training was still deemed complete by the code.
After some testing, it only happens after the job was stopped then restarted.
The logging hook and the scheduling hook, no longer agree on the value of the learning rate at that point.
In the last major [update](https://github.com/atomistic-machine-learning/schnetpack/pull/262), in file `src/schnetpack/train/trainer.py`, a `self.` was removed in line 114. Putting it back solves the problem, but I haven't looked in detail why. Not sure if this change had deeeper implications either.

Thanks again!
Olivier
